titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bartos Company Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Jessica Quagliaroli

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 15, 2019 at 08:01

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Bartos Company records includes include photographs, publicity materials, press clippings, magazine articles, and drawings documenting the furniture and woodworking business The Bartos Company (originally M. Bartos & Company). The bulk of the collection documents work produced by The Bartos Company from the 1920s to 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records include photographs, publicity materials, press clippings, magazine articles, and drawings documenting the furniture and woodworking business The Bartos Company (originally M. Bartos & Company). The bulk of the collection documents work produced by The Bartos Company from the 1920s to 1950s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged in five series: I. Period Drawings, 1926-1944. II. Photographs, 1930-1950. III. Publications and Publicity, 1924-1970. IV. Scrapbooks, 1938-1950. V. Samples, Ordering, and Administrative Materials, 1936-1940.

Records were arranged by the donor, Jim Bartos, but did not come to him in an original order from the company. Jim Bartos arranged records by type and subject, and staff of Manuscripts and Archives maintained most of that ordering, with the exception of the Scrabooks (reorganized into Series IV) and the Samples, Ordering, and Administrative Materials (reorganized into Series V).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Bartos Company was founded around 1900 by Mor Bartos, a Hungarian emigrant residing in New York City. Originally named M Bartos & Co., the company made high quality, custom-made period furniture for clients such as French & Co., Tiffany & Co., and William Randolph Hearst. In the early to mid-1900s companies such as French & Co. handled the interior decoration of furniture for rooms brought over from European houses to be reassembled in the United States. M Bartos & Co. made reproductions of original European furniture, intended to be indistinguishable from the originals. French & Co. used these furniture pieces to complete the reassembled rooms. M Bartos & Co. continued to work in this fashion until 1929.

Harold Bartos, son of Mor Bartos, took over the company in 1928 when Mor Bartos suddenly passed away from a heart attack. The company was then renamed The Bartos Company. After taking design and architectural classes at Columbia University, Harold Bartos became a designer and maker of furniture. He shifted the company from period to modern funiture and architectural woodwork. The Bartos Company made custom pieces to an architect's specifications as part of a larger project, such as executive offices, private residences, and public spaces. Examples of public projects include an acoustical ceiling for Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center and the redevelopment of the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In the 1940s, Harold Bartos co-founded and was the design producer of the Lehigh Furniture Co., which produced high quality furniture that could be ordered from a catalog. The Lehigh Furniture Co. was known for its innovative techniques with foam upholstery. The Lehigh Furniture Co. was later purchased by Litton Industries and merged with the Leopold Company to form Lehigh-Leopold Furniture. Throughout his career, Harold Bartos was active in The Architectural League of New York.
The Bartos Company dissolved in 1975 after the death of Harold Bartos.
Biographical information provided by Jim Bartos.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is available for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Bartos Company Records (MS 2074). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Duplicate materials were removed from the collection. Acetate Negatives will be digitally reformatted and then destroyed.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright interests in the collection materials held by The Bartos Company have been transferred by the donor to Yale University. Nonetheless, the collection materials may contain content owned by third-party copyright holders. Determination of the copyright status of specific material may require extensive research and it is the responsibility of researchers and others intending to use the materials to secure permission of the appropriate copyright holder(s). All other uses not requiring permission of third-party copyright holders are permitted only in accordance with the restrictions and requirements specified herein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the sketches and original drawings in this series are from French & Co. projects for which The Bartos Company supplied period furniture. Some drawings contain the product numbers for furniture pieces provided. Also found in this series are sketches and blueprints from the original IBM Building (1938-1977) located at 590 Madison Avenue in New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The drawings are arranged according to size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series show the range of furniture pieces produced by The Bartos Company. The French & Co. and period photographs contain product numbers and dimensions on the back of the physical photograph. The furniture pieces in these photographs are the same furniture pieces depicted in the period drawings in Series I.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by format type. Folders withing format types are arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: French & Co. furniture, Italian chair - tripod, product nos. 12829 - 12366
French & Co. furniture, oak console - Italian table, product nos. 34211 - 15606
French & Co., pine room, miscellaneous carving

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Due to degredation, the physical negatives will be discarded after digitization.

did.unittitle: Exhibit - 15th Exhibition of Contemporary American Industrial Art, The Metropolitan Museum of Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains trade catalogs, furniture and interior design publications, and publicity articles highlighting The Bartos Company. This series also includes a transcription of the CBS radio interview "The Cabinet Maker," which recorded Harold Bartos at his furniture shop.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by format type. Folders within format types are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The scrapbooks in this series contain articles, clippings, and photographs documenting the work of The Bartos Company and Lehigh Furniture Company. The scrapbooks provide some of the only documentation of Harold Bartos's work with the Lehigh Furniture Company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains administrative materials of The Bartos Company. Included are wooden marquetry inlay samples and an Order and Receipt Book. The photo catalog books contain photographs of each piece of furniture produced that was available to order. Most photographs have the product number and dimensions written on the back of the photograph.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by format type. Folders within format types are arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Letter from David Miller to Charles Hanson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letter is from David Miller, Secretary of the Manufacturing Woodworkers Association to Charles W. Hanson, President of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. Harold Bartos served on the Executive Committee of the Manufacturing Woodworkers Association.
